hints.content:
The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is the number of equal parts being counted.

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is the number of equal parts in **one** whole. 

$\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{numerator}}}{\blueD{\text{denominator}}}$

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is $\blueD6$, so we need $\blueD6$ equal pieces in each whole.

The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is $\purpleD{7}$, so we need $\purpleD7$ equal parts shaded.

The following images show $\dfrac76$ shaded:


[[☃ image 1]]


[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 6 parts. The first rectangle has 4 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 3 parts shaded. !
Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts. The first rectangle has 5 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 2 parts shaded. !

question.content:
Each large rectangle represents $1$ whole.

**Which images show $\dfrac76$ shaded?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.content: ![Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts. The first rectangle has 2 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 4 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9fbeb10679913e6373701890290478e4dfd2ac09)

![Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 8 parts. The first rectangle has 7 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 6 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ce17764fb5deb86b39df533e189a4a20821985d7)

![Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 6 parts. The first rectangle has 4 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 3 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a05162657a5de7da0bd0ca00e6185a4b75aada1d)

![Two rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts. The first rectangle has 5 parts shaded. The second rectangle has 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c5665473cb34718e88771481033b75083d377a1a)
